Himmelsbach | Jones unplugs, tunes in for Cards

Jones finishes 3 for 6 with a pair of 3s and 11 points

Himmelsbach | Jones unplugs, tunes in for Cards

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 11:50 p.m. EST December 5, 2014

Louisville's Chris Jones (3) drives around FIU's Tashawn Desir (3) on Friday at the KFC Yum! Center. UofL won 82-57. (By David Lee Hartlage, Special to the C-J) Dec. 5, 2014.(Photo: David Lee Hartlage, Special to the C-J)

2 CONNECT 8 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Louisville point guard Chris Jones sat at his locker after the Cardinals' 82-57 win over Florida International on Friday night, and his phone sat in his lap. It was face-down, and it stayed face-down the entire time, and there was something symbolic about that.

This season has been a struggle for Jones. He entered this game having made just 22 of 77 field-goal attempts this season, and it was clear that he was pressing. On Thursday, Cardinals coach Rick Pitino made it clear Jones should spend more time setting screens and less time staring at them.

"I think he reads that phone too much," Pitino said. "He's on it every second of the day. Doesn't get enough sleep. ... I guarantee that if he loses (the phone) for two weeks, he'll play great basketball."

Jones' phone is not gone. It was sitting there. Of course he still uses it, and no one would really expect him to completely stop. But he said he is now managing it better. It's not as constant, and, most importantly, it's not as distracting.

U of L coach Rick Pitino recaps the Cardinals' win over FIU.

Specifically, Jones has not been using social media as much. He has not been reading all the comments and critiques about his play. When you're in a rut, everyone has an answer. And then the voices build up and the noise rises and it becomes difficult to settle in and focus.

This was just one game, and it was against lowly Florida International, but Chris Jones unplugged is off to a good start. The senior was 3-for-6 from the floor—including a pair of 3-pointers—and finished with 11 points, three assists and three steals. Previously, he had not made half of his shots in any game this season.

"I got people telling me I need to do this and need to do that and it was getting to me a little bit, so I just blocked all that out and played basketball," Jones said. "There were so many voices, so many people talking, so I blocked it, and tonight it showed. I played very good."

MORE: U of L beats FIU with sharp shooting

MORE: Transcript: Rick Pitino on U of L's FIU win

After going 3-for-15 in the Cardinals' win over Ohio State on Tuesday, Jones went to the U of L practice court with his girlfriend — well after midnight — and spent about a half-hour working on his jump-shot.

"I think I was second-guessing a lot of my shots, and that's part of why I was missing," he said. "So I went to the gym and shot how I shot, and came out and did it today."

Now, of course, he will need to build on this game. If U of L is to be Final Four-caliber team, it will need large doses of good Chris Jones. There will be nights when Montrezl Harrell, Terry Rozier or Wayne Blackshear are in foul trouble or simply scuffling. There will be a night when Jones has a chance to drain one big shot for one big win.

U of L guard Terry Rozier updates his finger injury

And so maybe Friday night will signal the start of his rejuvenation. I asked Jones if there had been a time in his brief Louisville career when everything felt perfect, when he felt like the guard who had been named a national junior college player of the year. He smiled and his answer came instantly.

He said it was last season's game at Southern Methodist, when he scored 21 points and gathered six steals. That was also the first game after the death of his half-brother.

"That was a perfect one," Jones said before pausing for a moment. "And, tonight felt kind of perfect."

So maybe this is the start.

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach​
